history.content:
With Ranade this semester it was very reasonable, I'd say a bit lighter than 70/170 but generally similar. Problem sets took me around 4-7ish hours.

Edit: I disagree with the person below, imo the 127 exams (especially the final) were easier than the homeworks. 

__________________________

One thing to consider though is that unlike 126 and 16B, where exams are generally easier/same difficulty as the HWs, this is not the case for 127. Not sure whether you want to factor that into your decision, but I figured more information is better.

Edit: Actually, I agree with the person above on the final being easier. However, I would disagree for the midterm, and as far as I know, it's a general pattern too.

With Ranade this semester it was very reasonable, I'd say a bit lighter than 70/170 but generally similar. Problem sets took me around 4-7ish hours.

children.subject: Can i take this course if I havent taken a linear algebra course in 2 years? I looked at the EE127 diagnostic quiz from one of the prior semesters, and realized I forgot quite a lot :/
You'd definitely have to self-study a bit, the course has some review, but it's not a lot and it proceeds quite quickly. Nothing crazy though, 16AB level should be fine
@mouse where did you find the diagnostic quiz for ee127?
Math 110 is probably a good class to take before if you want to review basics of linear algebra

Yeah I'd add it was definitely reasonable workload, 4-7 hrs per problem set seems about right. Although I personally found the content itself more challenging to wrap my head around, so it took me some additional time to read the textbook/review notes every week and understand the material with simple examples before solving the more challenging homework problems. Also good to have a study group for when you get stuck.

imo the hws were a lot more than the 4-7 hours mentioned above / required several days -- a lot of work if you procrastinate a lot, like me (AKA I often started working on HWs day of, and would get around a 60-70% at best, when the class average on homeworks was around a 90%). bayen is a fantastic professor, but the homeworks were... a Lot. that being said, my perspective is a little biased because I personally found 127 to be both boring and difficult, so I struggled a lot to put effort into the homeworks. that being said, if you're able to do that and you're interested in 127, it did help me step up my mathematical maturity & was helpful in 189!
how was the workload for Bayen's version of 127?
what are the thoughts of el ghaoui's version of 127?

history.content: How much workload is EECS 127? I'm considering taking it in the fall with a handful of other technicals and I wanted to make sure that I wouldn't be overloading myself. I noticed it's mostly a problem set class - how long do the problem sets take? For reference I spent about 10 hrs a week doing work for EECS 126 when I took it this past semester and about 8 hrs a week doing work for EECS 16B this past semester (not including lab). Thanks!
history.subject: EECS 127 Workload
